in the swim of the summer popcorn movie

blamed and sometimes celebrated for
kicking off the whole Hollywood summer
blockbuster phenomenon Jaws directed by
Steven Spielberg and adapted from Peter
Benchley's runaway bestseller one of the
interesting things about jaws is how
little it really has in common with the
state of the art blockbusters of today
it has a great realistic sense of place
it's very character driven it often
moves very slowly and it doesn't really
have a lot of high-tech state-of-the-art
special effects now there is of course
an animatronic shark but he famously
makes a little more than a cameo
appearance in his own movie this is
partly because Steven Spielberg and his
crew had real trouble getting this
monster to work but this really works to
the film's advantage because Spielberg
can use things like the shark's own
point of view and deployed John
Williams's eerie spooky score to create
a seamless and effective feeling of
dread
those things are what make the movies

the characterizations Roy Scheider one

generation making the most of a fairly
underwritten part as the new york city
cop transplanted to a tranquil seaside
community there's Richard Dreyfuss as

the Captain Ahab of shark hunters in
